columns.text: In this problem, we will determine which credit policy will best fit the objective of the company.

First we must solve for the net present value of the current policy. To do this, we first need to solve for the average daily sales of the current policy. To do this, we can simply take the annual sales and divide it by $365$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Average daily sales}&=\dfrac{\$134,000,000}{365}\\[15 pt]
&=\$367,123.29
\end{aligned}$$

The average daily sales of the current policy is $\$367,123.29$

Next, we will solve for the costs. The first cost that we will solve for is the variable costs which is given as $45\%$ of the annual cost.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Daily variable costs}&=\dfrac{0.45\times\$134,000,000}{365}\\
&=\$165,205.48
\end{aligned}$$

Next cost is the cost brought about by defaults which is $1.6\%$ of the sales for this policy.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of defaults}&=\dfrac{0.016\times \$134,000,000}{365}\\
&=\$5,873.97
\end{aligned}$$

Finally, we can solve for the administrative costs by taking the annual sales and multiplying it by the rate of $2.2\%$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Administrative costs}&=\dfrac{0.022\times \$134,000,000}{365}\\
&=\$8,076.71
\end{aligned}$$

We can then get the total costs by taking the sum of the values in Step 4.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total costs}&=\$165,205.48+\$5,873.97+\$8,076.71\\
&=\$179,156.16
\end{aligned}$$

The total costs for this policy is $\$179,156.16$.

We will now solve for the interest rate. To do this, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{\text{Annual rate}}{\text{365}}\right)^{\text{Receivables period}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the annual rate of $6\%$ and the receivables period of $37$ days, we will get an interest rate of:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{0.06}{365}\right)^{37}-1\\[15 pt]
&=0.0061
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the needed values to the formula in Step 2, we will get the NPV of this policy which is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\$165,205.48+\dfrac{\$367,123.29-\$179,156.16}{0.0061}\\[15 pt]
&=\$30,979,489.09
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this policy is $\$30,979,489.09$. This means that in order to choose which policy is the best alternative, the net present value of that policy must be higher than the current plan.

For Option 1, we will repeat the same process above. We first need to solve for the average daily sales of the current policy. To do this, we can simply take the annual sales and divide it by $365$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Average daily sales}&=\dfrac{\$158,000,000}{365}\\[15 pt]
&=\$432,876.71
\end{aligned}$$

The average daily sales for Option 1 is $\$432,876.71$.

Next, we will solve for the costs. The first cost that we will solve for is the variable costs which is given as $45\%$ of the annual cost.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Daily variable costs}&=\dfrac{0.45\times\$158,000,000}{365}\\
&=\$194,794.52
\end{aligned}$$

Next cost is the cost brought about by defaults which is $2.5\%$ of the sales for this policy.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of defaults}&=\dfrac{0.025\times \$158,000,000}{365}\\
&=\$10,821.92
\end{aligned}$$

Finally, we can solve for the administrative costs by taking the annual sales and multiplying it by the rate of $3.2\%$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Administrative costs}&=\dfrac{0.032\times \$158,000,000}{365}\\
&=\$13,852.05
\end{aligned}$$

We can then get the total costs by taking the sum of the values in Step 9.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total costs}&=\$194,794.52+\$10,821.92+\$13,852.05\\
&=\$219,468.49
\end{aligned}$$

The total costs for this policy is $\$219,468.49$.

We will now solve for the interest rate. To do this, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{\text{Annual rate}}{\text{365}}\right)^{\text{Receivables period}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the annual rate of $6\%$ and the receivables period of $40$ days, we will get an interest rate of:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{0.06}{365}\right)^{40}-1\\[15 pt]
&=0.0067
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the needed values to the formula in Step 2, we will get the NPV of this policy which is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\$194,794.52+\dfrac{\$432,876.71-\$219,468.49}{0.0067}\\[15 pt]
&=\$32,046,767.65
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this policy is $\$32,046,767.65$.

For Option 2, we will repeat the same process above. We first need to solve for the average daily sales of the current policy. To do this, we can simply take the annual sales and divide it by $365$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Average daily sales}&=\dfrac{\$155,000,000}{365}\\[15 pt]
&=\$424,657.53
\end{aligned}$$

The average daily sales for Option 2 is $\$424,657.53$.

Next, we will solve for the costs. The first cost that we will solve for is the variable costs which is given as $45\%$ of the annual cost.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Daily variable costs}&=\dfrac{0.45\times\$155,000,000}{365}\\

Next cost is the cost brought about by defaults which is $1.8\%$ of the sales for this policy.

$$\begin{aligned}

Finally, we can solve for the administrative costs by taking the annual sales and multiplying it by the rate of $2.4\%$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Administrative costs}&=\dfrac{0.024\times \$155,000,000}{365}\\

We can then get the total costs by taking the sum of the values in Step 14.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total costs}&=\$191,095.89+\$7,643.84+\$10,191.78\\
&=\$208,931.51
\end{aligned}$$

The total costs for this policy is $\$208,931.51$.

We will now solve for the interest rate. To do this, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{\text{Annual rate}}{\text{365}}\right)^{\text{Receivables period}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the annual rate of $6\%$ and the receivables period of $50$ days, we will get an interest rate of:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{0.06}{365}\right)^{50}-1\\[15 pt]
&=0.0083
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the needed values to the formula in Step 2, we will get the NPV of this policy which is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\$191,095.89+\dfrac{\$424,657.53-\$208,931.51}{0.0083}\\[15 pt]
&=\$26,182,182.64
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this policy is $\$26,182,182.64$.

For Option 3, we will repeat the same process above. We first need to solve for the average daily sales of the current policy. To do this, we can simply take the annual sales and divide it by $365$.

$$\begin{aligned}

Next, we will solve for the costs. The first cost that we will solve for is the variable costs which is given as $45\%$ of the annual cost.

$$\begin{aligned}

\end{aligned}$$

Next cost is the cost brought about by defaults which is $2.2\%$ of the sales for this policy.

$$\begin{aligned}

\end{aligned}$$

Finally, we can solve for the administrative costs by taking the annual sales and multiplying it by the rate of $3.0\%$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Administrative costs}&=\dfrac{0.030\times \$170,000,000}{365}\\
&=\$13,972.60
\end{aligned}$$

We can then get the total costs by taking the sum of the values in Step 19.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total costs}&=\$209,589.04+\$10,246.58+\$13,972.60\\
&=\$233,808.22
\end{aligned}$$

The total costs for this policy is $\$233,808.22$.

We will now solve for the interest rate. To do this, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{\text{Annual rate}}{\text{365}}\right)^{\text{Receivables period}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the annual rate of $6\%$ and the receivables period of $48$ days, we will get an interest rate of:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest rate}&=\left(1+\dfrac{0.06}{365}\right)^{48}-1\\[15 pt]
&=0.0079
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the needed values to the formula in Step 2, we will get the NPV of this policy which is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\$209,589.04+\dfrac{\$465,753.42-\$233,808.22}{0.0079}\\[15 pt]
&=\$29,569,740.94
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this policy is $\$29,569,740.94$.

To summarize the net present values of the different options, we can use this table:


| Option| Net present value| 
|--|--| 
|Current |$30,979,489.09 | 
|Option 1 | $32,046,767.65| 
|Option 2 |$26,182,182.64 | 
|Option 3 | $29,569,740.94| 


As we can see, only **Option 1** has a higher Net present value compared to the current option which means that the company should go with Option 1.
